posts.com:
Not to say there aren't subpar versions of these games (because there clearly are) but I find it a little fascinating how easily you can tell the agerange/experience of people who suggest certain versions of the classic Final Fantasies. You can divide it into at least three major phases:
>1987-2003 (Famicom-PlayStation): The Square Era. The company respects its legacy catelog and may do some QoL here and there for re-releases but otherwise leaves the experience relatively untouched. For oldies.
>2004-2020 (Advance+): The Square Enix Era. The merger fundamentally shifts priorities and the company no longer sees the classic games in the same light, suddenly perceiving flaws that must in some way be "corrected" in each successive re-release, effectively pulling a Lucas except replace George with mostly random employees. For newbies.
>2021-present (Pixel Remaster): The Postmodern Era. In the wake of the abject failure of the later re-releases, the company receives word that pixels are "in" and commissions a new coat of paint that outwardly goes back to the tried-and-true basics, but upon closer inspection carries over much of what was done to these games in the previous phase, creating hodgepodge versions that don't strictly belong in either phase. For plebs.

WSC introduced a lot of changes to FF and FFII that have carried over to all the subsequent versions, and WSC/PSX both completely changed the graphics for current tech like the PSP and mobile phone releases. SNES games just got direct ports to PSX (which suck) because the display format didn't change significantly between those two consoles. Similar reasoning as to why FFVII-IX weren't touched until the last decade, since they could just straight up be played on a PS2 and PS3.

Thief was hit the hardest in terms of bugs. It's supposed to make up for its weaknesses in sheer luck and agility, but in practice, it's a total paperweight. Meanwhile, both the Black and White Mages are simply too damn squishy even accounting for bugfixed Int, and taking full advantage of them by decking out their magic slots makes them lowkey the most expensive classes to maintain, so they're hardly worth wasting slots. This ironically makes the default party of the NES/MSX version the best beginner-friendly one in the long run since it has the most reasonable variety; in the original/bugged version, Thief is just too much of a drag in the long run and you're better off replacing it with literally anything else. I dunno why remakes then swap out Monk and Red Mage for White and Black Mages. That's just a straight-up worse setup even in those versions. >>9585613
> All the good magic can be learned by Red Wizard
Due to the way the magic scaling works in remakes, doubling in base power at thresholds of 20, 30, 40, 50 etc., the Red Wizard will have what amounts to base level magic power of the NES/PSX versions still when nearing level 50, not breaking 30 until or after that point, while the Black Mage has gotten 1~2 extra layers of damage at any one point in the game. Then there's the overpowered healing items, standard MP system and other changes that change the game in a major way.
There simply is no need for Black Magic outside of Haste and Temper in the later versions due them being based on the easy version of PSX. The abundant healing items and overinflated leveling speed means that you're not in danger of being whittled down, and any damage your fighters deal is enough to one shot enemies, while your MP dependent mages will be either barely missing out on kills. For bosses you Temper/Haste/Giants glove the Master and one or two shot the bosses, save for Chaos. Even the Lich is handled easily with Diaga spells from your White Mage.
Personally I go for
>NES/PSX: Knight, Master, Red Wizard, White Wizard
>Later Versions: Knight, Master, Ninja, White Wizard.

Ps. please format you posts, it's really hard to read a wall of text with no breaks.

FF1 sort of followed DQ2's way to using towns as a hubs but in a lighter way. Then sadly, after DQ3's success, everyone started copying what DQ3 did, whether those things were improvements or not, and we got lot's of RPGs consisting of "enter new area with 1 town, 1 dungeon, move to next area with 1 town, 1 dungeon, repeat"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9602084
It's more than visual fluff. The Pixel Remaster is (surprise) the easiest one between the Famicom and 3D versions. Back in the DS version, the monster limit was crunched due to perceived hardware limitations, so stats/classes were rebalanced across the board to make up for it. It wasn't perfect, but it got the job done and general game difficulty wasn't as wildly thrown off as some people make it seem. At worst, maybe the boss AI could've been improved. Pixel Remaster is aesthetically closer to the Famicom original, but it still carries over and builds upon a staggering amount of 3D remake changes under the hood, especially the parts of it that give you an easier time without regard for why that was done in the first place. Many of the added class abilities were kept, giving you a bigger edge in battle. The capacity system was replaced yet again, but whereas the 3D version gave you a reasonable adjustment period, PR now has absolutely nothing there to keep you in check. And while the formations are ostensibly based on the original, the monster locations are based on the 3D version; an easy example, Goblins only appear in Altar Cave in the original, while in the 3D and PR versions, they keep appearing well after the cave and show up in and around town, which is normally the point you're supposed to be moving on to the next phase of monsters. Oddly enough, a similar change may have been planned for the WonderSwan Color version
>>9600631, but it at least looks like they would've increased the number of outdoor Goblins to compensate (or it was just a test shot). Plus, in Pixel Remaster, game overs mean very little and the game freely allows you to restart from the beginning of the area. Final Fantasy III isn't even one of the hardest games in the series, putting aside the long final dungeon that eluded playtesting. Overall, yes, there is much dumbing down in the Pixel Remaster, and the Famicom and DS versions both had greater respect for your resourcefulness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9601368
>What I want to know ultimately is: in what way was this level apparently worse than Wacky Workbench?
I have a theory requiring mild blank-filling. We have an overall impression over the years that R2 was removed due to it somehow being too slow-paced and janky. Well, we have this Amy gameplay concept courtesy of (I think) Sonic Origins. Something relevant here is that she had a role in R2, not R1&3, and indeed, she's missing from Salad Plain in the early proto, so it's likely she was at that point in development still bound for R2. It also seems that she had a somewhat bigger role originally. If I understand it right, here's what I believe the deal is: R2 was supposed to essentially be an ESCORT MISSION that served as a formal introduction to Amy. Maybe the idea was for players to get accustomed to her and even start to appreciate her help, possibly acting as a sort of tutorial to explore your surroundings, before she gets yanked away and motivates you to want to save her, but the execution was lacking and it ended up having the opposite effect in which she was a hindrance and players found her capture to be a relief. Thus it was an underground route filled with "ridicule" (Amy). Due to a combination of "what shrooms were we on" and time/space-constraints, the level was cut entirely instead of being reworked. The Amy gimmick was repurposed as a minor gag at the end of Palmtree Panic 1 present, and her kidnapping scene was moved to the start of R3 (Collision Chaos).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I like it. It can be a bit tricky to figure out the strategy. As long as you remember you are supposed to be a tiny elite group of whatever your side can pull together, and you are fighting against a virtually unlimited army, then it gets a lot easier to figure out what you should be doing. It's not a TBS game where you can afford to lose units. Losing even one unit is a massive disaster, and will handicap you for a few future missions if you continue on. There is no acceptable level of losses, there is no acceptable level of damage. Know exactly where you need to go, move fast, hit hard and fast, get out fast. All other tactics are suicide.
I remember the 1st mission being that easy "blow the dam" mission, and the 2nd being your own private slice of Vietnam where winning or losing was entirely dependent on your ability to use artillery and bombing jets. Then I remember something about a real difficulty curve of a mission where you can only bring 4 or 6 people for a jail-break for some VIP. Everything after that is kinda blurry except that bastard of a final mission. Had a full team armed to the teeth, and still barely pulled that one off.

>>9601237
The learning curve is a bit rough. As well as trying to figure out exactly what you have to work with. First off, your pilots. The important stats are AP(Action Points), DEF(ense), SCT(Scouting), AG(Attack against Ground), and AA(Attack against Air). Your best combat mechs and your biggest guns should go to the people with the highest AG. Never make someone with a shit SCT score a scout. It shouldn't be too tricky to figure that part out. Next, you have a few different mechs to choose from at first, and you'll get upgraded versions later on. One is the general mech with maximum mount points for equipment, one is the heavy armor mech with no shoulder weapons, one is the scout mech, and you have a special 2-seater mech for that 3rd mission that you will never use otherwise.
When it comes to equipment, you have a lot of options but the shoulder-mounted missiles rape all. Less ammo but you aren't supposed to be fighting battles, you're supposed to be taking out a target and running away. After that you just need to assign people to roles. Who's flying them in, who's in which squad, who's support air or artillery. Once on the battlefield, have your scouts on the edge of your formation and have them scan. Anything spotted should be nuked by your missiles or air/artillery support. If you are walking into the enemy, you are committing suicide. Scan, spot, smash, then scram.
Level 2 and level 3 are massive difficulty spikes. You won't see level 4 until you master air/artillery support and being able to blitzkrieg your way through heavy defenses.

James Pond is one of those European Amiga games that got console releases too.
Whenever people talk about it, it's always the second game Robocod, and I think usually the Genesis / Mega Drive version, and it's been re-released of a shitload of systems in some fashion, even Switch.

posts.com:
I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJag19WoAe0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOXFR5SQnYk

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597848
>Japan has been having a hard time
You seem to be unaware but Korea's electronics manufacturing is entirely dependent on Japan for ultra high tech components. Even 3 years after being removed from the trusted trade partners list they're still struggling to become unreliant on Japan. Moon boasted a while back that they were able to find replacements with European companies but what he didn't reveal that it was actually the European branches of the same Japanese companies that they were doing business with before, which means that they're still completely reliant on Japan.

Japan has largely moved away from producing consumer electronics except for a few brands who continue to make simple home goods like Panasonic and Hitachi, but a lot of those products are only for the domestic Japanese market. Japan instead has chosen to focus on patents and ultra high tech like supplying over half the global supply of robots for manufacturing. Companies with bad business decisions like Sony got bit in the ass by that decision for trying to compete against the same countries that they moved their manufacturing to.

>Post other examples

This is a Sigma Super Pro Stick. It's an arcade stick released by Supergun manufacturer Sigma. I think it came out in 1991, or early 1992. Very soon after SFII's arcade release.
From my research looking into issues of Gamest, Famitsu, and Game Machine magazine it is the first* six-button arcade stick.
Yet the design is something that is almost exactly what home arcade sticks would evolve into over the next several years/decades.
You could hand this to a tournament player today and they would be impressed.


*not counting products like the Combo AV that had the stick and buttons built into the body of the supergun.

the big mistake NEC made with bringing the PC Engine over to the US as the TurboGrafx 16 is that they wasted so much time and money on redesigning the system for the American market to be bigger when they should have used the PC Engine's tiny size as a selling point, market it as not only the video gaming equivalent to the Walkman or one of the Portable Computers of the era, but not wasting a bunch of time redesigning it also means they probably could have gotten it onto the US market in 1988 instead of 1989 giving them time to build up market share instead of having to immediately compete with the Sega Genesis and this also means that NEC could have honestly marketed the TurboGrafx at launch as being the legitimately most powerful gaming system in the US as it outperforms the NES in almost every respect(indeed I picture a lot of the marketing of this alternate TurboGrafx that maintains the original PC Engine design highlighting it's small size of both console and it's HuCards as being more advanced than the NES and it's cartridges being comparatively huge but having worse graphics)

there's no beating out a Nintendo that's successfully launched the NES in the US but NEC could have easily secured the 2nd place slot for a few years if they hadn't been dumb and wasteful and that in turn could have allowed them to hold onto being a console maker longer than in OTL

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600497
>>9600510
>>9600551
1. PC-E has a fast 8-bit CPU while the Mega Drive has a slightly less fast 16-bit CPU with 32-bit data width. The 65C02 assembly codes resemble that of the 6502 and have shorter and simpler commands than the 68000, thus it excelled at simple 2D tasks. The 68000 excelled at more complex tasks, allowing games to have more visual effects and even 3D rendering capability. It's just like comparing the 6502 to the Z80 or the 680.
2. PC-E's display controller is more straightforward from what I know. Yeah it could render more colors, but you couldn't have too much parallax effects, and 3D effects would be slower. And I think you could pull off some tricks on the MD to make it display more colors.
3. PC-E's 8KB scratchpad SRAM might have helped. The Mega Drive got a slower 64KB unified DRAM.
4. Japanese devs sucked at 68000 assembly, or they just didn't bother trying because the MD was much less commercially successful in Japan. The Amiga veterans working on Mega Drive games created tons of technically impressive games the PC-E couldn't even dream of running. There's nothing remotely comparable to Turrican 3, Duke Nukem 3D, and The Lost World on the PC-E. There are a few great looking Japanese MD games like Panorama Cotton, Ranger X, and Alien Soldier. Faceball's 4 screen multiplayer is pretty impressive though, but it's a horrible looking game, worse than the Atari 8-bit port.
5. Space Harrier looks like ass t.b.h. Outrun looks and runs better on the mega drive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594753
I see this take being posted a lot more often in recent years, and I couldn't disagree more. I know it's a matter of taste, and if you don't enjoy something I do then that's fine really, but I can't help but feel that a lot of people don't give Sonic a fair enough shot and end up missing out on experiences they might've loved otherwise. When it comes to Sonic, the reason you run into things and get hit is because, well, you're going fast and, depending on how quick your reflexes are, you might not be able to react to things in time, it's something that varies from player to player and that's fine, but I can see why some would go through this and assume that it's all memorization...

Still, all video games require us to memorize sections we're having trouble with, and we're not supposed to be good at a video game as soon as we pick it up, it'd be shallow otherwise, if you could just run and win, then no one would've cared about Sonic, it's a franchise that rewards you for sticking around. One more thing that can help, is that Sonic's vulnerable when he's just running, but not when he's jumping... or rolling into a ball, always make sure to press down in slopes, not only do you gain speed, but you also protect yourself. Also, if you prefer something like Mario, then I can't recommend Sonic's 8bit library enough, they're a lot more Mario like than the original Genesis installments, Sonic 1 is excellent on both Game Gear and Master System, if you go for Sonic 2 then always pick the Master System version, otherwise it's too punishing, but if you go for Sonic Chaos then go for Game Gear, otherwise it's too simple. I hope you can give Sonic another fair shot, but if you prefer not to then that's your choice, but trust me, they're excellent video games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think people start looking at these games from a modern POV, one from during the era of widespread speed and skill runs. Remember that it has passwords - the intent was for the games to first be played over a period of time, not just to be speedrun fodder right off the bat. You see an item or seemingly unreachable passage and note it. Later, you happen to find an upgrade, and realize it could perhaps be used to snag something from one of those previously inaccessible areas. Sure, the helmet upgrade is cheesy, but once you have it and realize you're missing some upgrades, you go back through stages and fire it off randomly to see what it picks up. Sure, you might think it stupid and cumbersome, but again, even though the X games can be cleared 100% in sub-hour times, that wasn't the way they were intended to be played your first time through. Put yourself in the shoes of a kid who got the game in the 90s, and it was either a rental serving as the focus of an entire weekend's worth of dicking around, or a purchased or gifted game meant to hold you over for at least a few weeks until you could get something new.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600930
To be fair, DX Sonic has a much higher polygon count than the DC version, but I agree that people overblow how "weak" the DC was. People forget that the DC can run most of its library in 480p, while the PS2 can mostly just manage to hit 480i (which is really just 240p but doubled). In truth, all the killer apps for all of the consoles of the time were highly specialized to the hardware they were built for, hence why most DC ports look dramatically worse on PS2, or sound better than on the GC. The DC definitely couldnt run the post-processing effects of SH2, but I don't think the texture work would be impossible as the DC has texture decompression, while the PS2 doesn't. I really think we never saw what the DC was completely capable of as a lot of techniques were developed later in the gen.

>>9599512
After becoming an adult and getting into classical music, the series' growing pretensions from 6 onward make me think they were actually trying to create interactive operas.

Operas often only change scenes at the beginning of a new act. So to tell a complete narrative in 3-5 scenes, exposition dumps are a big part of it. It can sometimes be like an episode of Springer with a dynamic soundtrack that reacts to two characters having an argument over something that happened offscreen and the details slowly emerge as they yell stuff at each other accusingly, for example. If you imagine the flashback scenes as the group talking to one another, and Uematsu's music being written to pull you into caring about the sudden left turn of the narrative, it makes sense.

I'm not saying its brilliant or that there wouldn't be a better way to do it, but as the series got more serious, its pretty obvious that they considered opera an artistic aspiration for the series and now that I'm familiar enough with the tropes of Wagner and Italian Verismo operatic storytelling, the way 6 onwards delivers story beats feels similar to the way Puccini (Aeris' death) or Wagner (giant, world ending sword duel climax) would present them.

>>9599610
Good post. Most FF fans are completely artistically illiterate and can't see any nuance. Sephiroth is shown to be cold and ruthless even when he was a "hero." He was raised to be a killing machine, held up as a figurehead for Shinra's propaganda, showered with praise for slaughtering any perceived enemy, and we learn from Lucretia that he was never even held by his mother as a baby; he was whisked off by scientists to be a research specimen the moment he was born. You don't need to be a psychologist to see how fucked up someone would be from living a life like that. Even before the Nibelheim incident, he was, at best, a functional sociopath with a massive superiority complex, but most players completely miss all of that and take the claim that he's a hero at face value.

I'd also argue that he doesn't actually give a shit about Jenova or the Ancients. Those are just post-hoc rationalizations he uses to justify his desires. When he reads in Gast's research notes that Jenova is an Ancient, he claims that entitles him to take the planet back from the humans who betrayed the Ancients. Later, when he travels through the Lifestream and learns the truth about Jenova (that she was actually just a monster that wiped out the Ancients), he twists it around and says that he's entitled to rule the planet because Jenova was even greater than the Ancients were. In other words, all he really wants is to satisfy his own ego by elevating himself up to godhood compared to the rest of the world, and he'll use whatever excuse he can come up with to justify it.

>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

— Single low quality source.

>The Myth: The average person swallows eight spiders per year. Fear not. This "statistic" was not only made up out of whole cloth, it was invented as an example of the absurd things people will believe simply because they come across them on the Internet. In a 1993 PC Professional article, columnist Lisa Holst wrote about the ubiquitous lists of "facts" that were circulating via e-mail and how readily they were accepted as truthful by gullible recipients. To demonstrate her point, Holst offered her own made-up list of equally ridiculous "facts," among which was the statistic cited above about the average person's swallowing eight spiders per year, which she took from a collection of common misbeliefs printed in a 1954 book on insect folklore. In a delicious irony, Holst's propagation of this false "fact" has spurred it into becoming one of the most widely-circulated bits of misinformation to be found on the Internet.

On the other hand, some game directors were just too ambitious. Takahashi and Xenogears being the prime example. It's amazing when you think about how big some of the Square PS1 games were and how fast they were developed. The maximum development time allowed was typically 2 years, with little room for delays.

Even without the spoon, he works ok with an Artemis bow.

To answer the thread question though, probably make sing similar to the spell command but have a list of songs, each song has verses with various effects, and the idea is that you spend several turns ramping them up for their benefits. For example, "Aria" starts by casting a weak cure on the the first verse (turn), and then if you continue it next turn it gives everyone protect, and then it loops between a medium cure, a strong cure, and a group revive if you continue. "Dirge" would debuff enemies with slow, poison, stop, and finally death.

I don't really like Edward being a powerful character though, I think it's central to his arc that he accepts he's not a warrior but has other ways to aid Cecil in his quest. A lot of the supporting cast is that way, Cid for example wields a mean hammer but is first and foremost an airship engineer, Tellah is an old man past his prime, and the twins are still just children even if they are prodigies. Yang is the only one that really could fill the role of a hero in the party in my opinion, being an actual warrior from Fabul.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
He's a prince, who has focused on the delicate art of music, from a kingdom that has a weird hovercraft... I could see him being developed into an Edgar Figaro kind of party member who uses gadgets in battle. But his tools would be ones he encountered during the journey and discovered he could adapt himself to (thanks to his princely education, artistic sensibility, and clever fingers), not ones he designed himself.

From the start, he could do stuff with his harp(s) like what others here are suggesting. Then maybe while the group is staying the night among the underworld dwarves or Eblan's ninjas, he chats with some locals and gains basic training in some other clever mechanical or magical tool that he could use well thanks to his unusual set of strengths. Like, I don't know, a programmable doll the dwarves have that can carry a bomb to an enemy, or a small set of unique spells (kinda like Edge's spells) that he learns from some old scroll you find somewhere that nobody else can read because it uses an outmoded writing style that only fruity royal types and dusty scholars like Tellah ever learn (and Tellah's gone then). Maybe at some point he discovers he has a bit of aptitude for a certain kind of battle strategy and so can arrange for the party to surprise enemies and get first strike more often, or even to disrupt enemies with a trick in the middle of a battle and give the party a round's worth of free turns right then. He could just build up various odd abilities here and there, gradually becoming more useful and gaining confidence.

Then during the endgame he finally achieves his final form when you go deep into a lunar cavern and discover a set of ancient mech suits that are driven via piano keyboards or something, and nobody can get them to do anything except musical Edward, so now he's a cyborg with a shoulder-mounted cannon and he's as sturdy as Cecil. And also the ghost of Anna occasionally aids him in battle and she's naked and looks really pretty.

>>9601486

It's silly but it works fine in that version of the game. Free Enterprise demolishes the story by randomizing things and thus focuses on mechanics over all else - but it's not one of those T-Edition things where lots of content is added and reworked; it tries to keep the original game elements roughly unchanged aside from randomization. But it's not really fun for the player to have multiple characters in the character pool who can randomly bog you down by being permanently weak. Dark knight Cecil is so severely limited in stats and equipment that he seems to have been considered irredeemable challenge-run material by the mod authors, but Edward can be turned into a pretty decent character with just the one little change of giving him a single excellent weapon. Or something like that. And I guess they couldn't resist making a "spoony bard" joke by choosing a spoon to be that weapon. Anyway it's a good hack.

>most playthroughs spend more time moving thru magmoor than progressing in new areas
They really don't, Magmoor is a very direct area with little to stop your progress. Magmoor has extra elevators specifically to speed up backtracking like the one after Thardus and the one in Tallon Overworld.
>artifact hunt is only made more efficient by having done it in an earlier playthrough
You can get the hints to find all the artifacts when you get the Space Jump, early in the game. You don't have to go out of the way at all, it's right where you're already going.
>by knowing there's like 3 artifacts you can get early out of 14.
More like 6 out of 12. These are the artifacts you can get early without even leaving the critical path.
>Chozo (collect while getting x ray visor)
>Wild (collect on way to ice beam)
>Nature (collect on first visit to magmoor, many opportunities to collect later)
>Strength (collect while backtracking for space jump)
>Warrior (collect while backtracking for x ray visor)
>Truth (literally waiting for you in the temple)

Interestingly hitscan isn't very common on console shooters, even way back to the PS1. Did you know Duke Time to Kill has projectile bullets? Way back on the PS1. Really hitscan is mostly a PC thing and PC port thing.
>the enemies are the same braindead hitscanners
Metroid has plenty of enemy variety but sadly it's all far simpler than humanoid enemies filling various archetypes. That's one of the things that stood out to me most first playing Prime 20 years ago "wow the enemies sure as simple compared to Halo."
>grey + bloom graphics are not good or interesting.
I'm OK with graphical variety, after all it's not so much about the graphics it's about the gameplay. You have my permission to enjoy Metroid Prime's generic lava, desert, snow areas. Its visuals are truly dull and colorless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9602242
>As for the rest, that isn't really an issue, all these games used wheels in the arcade. You could probably set up a curve for your joysticks to improve the response.
I know what you are trying to say with a curve, but It doesn't matter what settings you use (I've tried all of them). Teknoparrot can't emulate a curve with a controller. You can look up gameplay videos of people trying to use a controller with driving games on YouTube. They all suffer the same issues. Jerky controllers. It's because the arcade version was never designed to use a controller. Only a steering wheel. Teknoparrot (even in the latest version) can't emulate a controller using a steering wheel properly. It's just jerky motion no matter what settings you try.

That's why if you are playing on PC, it's better to use the PC version. When it's ported to PC, the devs had to factor in multiple control schemes, program them into the game, and test them all to make sure they work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593316
>>9593773
Lord, you don't even understand that I wasn't advocating their use, and simply nudged to look at their inception.

Let's get back to mid-90s, when ability to play a video or an animation in a window didn't mean you could automatically do the same in full screen.

https://archive.org/details/CDROMToday11Jan1995/page/n59/mode/2up

Stretching a single bitmap to a different size was not an instant operation, and doing it many times a second could easily exceed both CPU performance and memory bandwidth with all the pixel copying. (Even today a scroll through resized photos in a viewer can be noticeably slower than a scroll through the same files at original size.) Software had to rely on system-provided, driver-provided, or its own optimized scaler functions to be as fast as possible. It often wasn't even proper nearest neighbor scaling, but a block-of-pixel-based assembly routines hard-coded for the specific CPU memory bus width and cache size (or, later, MMX, or, later, SSE), possibly with some fixed dithering.

It is funny that with all the retro circlejerk it's hard to find the video of just a regular video player being used on real hardware. Unique texturing algorithm choices on the first generation of 3D accelerators can give you an idea of speed-optimized scaling results:

https://www.vintage3d.org/images/AT3D/gallery.php
https://www.vintage3d.org/gallery/permedia.php
etc.

Due to hardware limitations, it was still often not possible to do something the straightforward way. Games could use interlaced 120 line video clips to fill the 240 line image because CD-ROM and system performance couldn't handle bigger data streams. When Windows 3.1 media player was told to play the video in full screen, it simply grabbed the video card exclusively, changed the video mode to a smaller and faster one, and bypassed the Windows GUI altogether.

Fast scalers, rotozoomers, and the rest were also important demoscene effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595074
So-called 2D (GUI) accelerators and hardware overlay boards (often with a genlock for external TV signal) that could stretch your bitmaps for you had already existed as a niche professional market. However, it was finally understood that all that multimedia and interactive media often needed to use it on every frame. Video cards began to have dedicated hardware for that (and also began to consume YUV video frames, freeing the CPU from converting each one to RGB after decoding). See how review mentions that the card can stretch the buffer with bilinear filtering (!):

https://archive.org/details/pcworld151unse/page/227/mode/1up

Wow, we have that tiny worse-than-VCD clip playing in full screen with smooth pixels! Of course, bilinear filtering also gives you lots of blur, especially when dealing small bitmaps like NES output buffer.

The problem with hardware stretching is that it is done in hardware. The overlay variant specifically happens after the whole frame buffer is consumed and processed, and treats it like a green screen over which the given image is overlaid (duh). Software couldn't guess how good was the quality of scaling, as computer couldn't even technically get the result back from the screen. Still, it was important to offload as much as possible to the hardware to save CPU performance for the main tasks. Composite and S-Video outputs that later appeared often on regular video cards worked in the same black box manner. How exactly TV picture was generated from output buffer (the whole screen or active accelerated surface) was defined by chip makers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595076
In addition, a fixed set of desktop resolutions everyone used (640×480, 800×600, 1024×768) did not align well with console screen resolutions. Today you can integer scale that 256×244 to any ratio almost up to 10×. Back then, unless the emulator was a dedicated full screen application, you had to compromise by cutting part of the picture or making it smaller than the desktop (not so great when your monitor was already small). The other alternative was to zoom 2× or 3x, then slightly resize the output, and have either smudged or uneven pixels.

And of course, the aspect ratio of TV console output pixels is not 1:1, so to correct the almost-square picture to (more or less physically correct) 4:3, you had to stretch with different coefficients vertically and horizontally.

On the one hand, hardware scaling on a specific system with a specific hardware using specific resolution could be a blurry mess, a blocky mess, or a combination of both. On the other hand, emulators had to use it in most cases, and had to be prepared for that. The idea of all those 2× and 3x filters was to implement fast enhancing upscale (instead of the regular pixel doubled or pixel tripled copy) that would help contrast lines (e. g. text on screen) to survive the uncontrollable external stretching. They compensated for the less than stellar processing down the path.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9595080
You can open any image editor, and try stretching the original buffer, its 2× or 3× copies, and 2× or 3× filtered copies to the same random output resolutions with nearest neighbor and bilinear filtering, and decide which results look less horrible to you.

Then after a couple of years, a couple of processor and video card families, and a couple of DirectX versions letting software interact with hardware through new APIs, it all slowly stopped being relevant. The rest is just wanking. First, some developers decided that all the increased computing power should better be spent on magical algorithms that could convert pixel art into high resolution graphics (they couldn't). Second, clueless users who discovered scaling options mistook them for some important improvements that could be used on their own.

If you have all the modern CPU and GPU performance to produce something that looks similar enough to the original thing, you never need the filters that were used in year 1999 to solve year 1999 problems.

posts.com:
>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

Spin stick and time your attack to do a spin attack, tilt stick forward and attack to stab, tilt stick right and attack to swing right, tilt stick left to attack to swing left, hold attack to charge, etc. Especially the spin always feels so good and right to do

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

>>9587326
I think it's an issue of standards changing. Nowadays, you'd get an E10+ or T rating from those elements. In the late '90s, however, people seemed to just care less about the degree of violence that appeared in children's media. So, you could get away with a little blood and death, especially if it was subtly put in.

The clearest example of "they could never get away with that today" in an E-rated game I can think of is Mega Man X4. One cutscene has a character slash some others in half as dark red blood splatters everywhere. Even with the whole "they're robots, so it's not really blood" defense, that scene seemingly got the X Collection a T rating alone.

>>9595983

The strength of Persona games (unlike mainline SMT ones) comes from the characters being interesting as are their private issues that are laid bare as the plot progresses. There's a lot of sin, decadence, perversion and so on that unravels. That's where the main interest lies.

But the obnoxious rate of random encounters and the typical SMT-type dungeon slogs drag it down because they sap away the momentum of the experience. Later games in the series realized that and put more emphasis on the character stuff and reduced the tedium of dungeon crawling.
It's not that the dungeon crawling is bad conceptually, but in each dungeon (or location equivalent) it FAR outstays it's welcome and becomes a chore. This is true in almost every SMT game, but like I said, in Persona games the interest lies in the characters, while in SMT games it's more about the overall atmosphere of the setting.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9590557
The date scenes are almost too subtle for their own good. The game is amazing at narrative subterfuge, setting up the audience for a love triangle only to hint that there's something more going on. The language implies lovey dovey but the underlying meaning is way more straight forward. Aeris tells Cloud that he doesn't have to pretend to be someone else and that she'd rather meet the real person. Again, like a big sister telling her kid brother to stop pretending to be something he's not. With Tifa's date she tries to say something and backs off. She says "Aeris would be able to say it" or something along those lines. You think that it's an attempt at a love confession but it's really Tifa trying to confront Cloud about his bullshit and Tifa is acknowledging that Aeris is way more assertive than she is. Both girls are trying to use the date to have an intervention and the love triangle gimmick is the smoke and mirrors to disguise it to the player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think she's more important to Cloud based on his memories of his mother, where his flashbacks of her in Nibelheim are probably his most authentic. This makes the most sense because he never really knew or understood Zack's parents in Gongaga to really appropriate, and even when you do meet them, they act very different from Cloud's memories of his mother. Meanwhile, that Cloud in the flashbacks with his mother is probably the truest version of Cloud we see until the actual reveal come last disc.

She tells him to look for an older woman who can keep him in line, and Aeris does happen to be older, and while that isn't important, I do think the conversation hints more at why he's drawn to Aeris and the way she talks to him, even if that kiddish honesty of hers isn't exactly romantic and more arm's length, which is a luxury Tifa lacks and explains why she can never get to the point with him and can only say nothing at all for a long time.

I like the Cloud and Aeris pairing, but I don't think they were ever romantically drawn to one another. Cloud at most probably relates her to his mother, and that's why losing her feels hurts, but his inability to protect Tifa hits him so differently in comparison, he has to completely compartmentalize and repress the fact until he's no longer allowed to.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9596485
The grades exist to nudge you into playing the game in a way that will be more fun and skillful. It's basically an informal difficulty selection, if you're okay with getting a sub-par rank on every level the game will be easier but less satisfying, just like as if you had played on easy.

Anyway, there are benefits to being considerate about how you attack but I'll grant you don't NEED to do it to beat the game, but even so you need to do things besides button mashing to avoid damage, unless you just tank it all with items but again that's playing on babby mode and an impractical playstyle that's essentially equivalent to skipping the gameplay.

That said, I do kinda get the sense this genre pushes you much harder to learn how to properly defend than it does how to attack. Learning how to deal a lot of damage, combo, or improve your style rank/score is all a lot more optional than learning how to not get hit, and I think it can contribute to these games feeling more button-mashy on a casual level. Something that also bothers me about them is that for all the hype around sick combos, a lot of the enemies can't be meaningfully combo'd. Humanoid bosses in particular can often be stunned, allowing you to wail on them for a bit, but no matter what you do to them during these sections they just sit there: you can't move or manipulate them in any way, all you can do is deal damage. It's lame - I'm not saying you should be able to infinitely combo them, but if they're going to have a "vulnerable" state you can trigger, make them comboable when in that state.

>>9596384
Devil May Cry is considered a hack and slash game, which typically involves fast-paced, combo-based combat. The game does rely on button mashing to a certain extent, but it also requires players to master a variety of different techniques and mechanics in order to be successful. This includes mastering different weapons and abilities, juggling enemies in the air, and dodging enemy attacks.

Some players might find the game to be button-mashing, but many fans consider Devil May Cry to be a more skill-based game that requires players to master the mechanics and develop their own playstyle to truly excel.

It's also worth noting that opinions on games are subjective, some people may find the game to be too simplistic while others may think that it's deep and challenging. What is important is that you enjoy playing the game and you find it fun.

Frames of delay, giving the rollback netcode the leeway to work. More frames of delay means higher input lag (ovbiously) but a stabler experience (less teleports)

>>9591461
I'm a Link main, and while it's true quite a bit of lag was lopped off his movements and some of his attacks in Brawl and afterward, he's still MUCH more fun to play in Melee regardless once you've gained a degree of mastery over his moveset. You can projectile spam to your heart's content, with a great deal of control over his projectiles (his bombs have great interaction potential, as does his boomerang). You can settle for a balance of projectile spam at long range with shffld aerials in the short range. Or you can even surprise your opponents and go on a full retard aggressive shffld aerial offensive with few to no projectiles (this last one is the weakest, but can catch opponents off-guard since not many would play Link this way). His edge and recovery game is also fun thanks to his wall tethers which give him tools to keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path. Mind you, despite all this he still gets shit on by the top tiers, especially the space animals, but he's not as clunky as people think, and he's horribly simplified in later versions and IMO nowhere near as fun to dick around with.

>>9592695
Link and Y. Link's Hookshot and Samus's Grapple Beam. When used off-stage, unlike in Brawl and beyond, they can hang onto pretty much any wall at any point, and several cool things can be done with them. You can extend them up and down, and can be canceled with a button press at any point from the moment they make contact with the wall to when you're hanging down, at which point your character will quickly "jump" upwards. If you're skilled, this makes their recoveries more dynamic and can keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path, and IIRC you can even attack out of cancelling. It's really fucking fun, and their removal in favor of a boring auto-snap onto the ledge was a travesty but in keeping with Sakurai's overall drive to casualize the shit out of Smash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9601789
That game was released way past the time the SFC had steafy releases; everyone moved onto N64/Saturn/PS1 and Capcom released this game for people that couldn't afford any of the current gen consoles but still had a Super Famicom.
Rockman & Forte is a love letter to fans but it reuses a lot of stuff, namely two bosses, spritework and assets from Megaman 8. Basically, Rm&F was the developers pushing a lot of a console they knew by that time like the palm of their hands without expecting thr average profit the company sought on the market back then.
On 7's defense, though, the game has a lot of throwbacks and collectibles that also make it a great game, but design/artstyle decisions hurt the gameplay a lot and some people regard the game as inferior; it looks and sounds great, but not for a fast paced game like the Megaman series.

>>9601924
You must be too young to remember.

At that time, the Wii's Virtual Console were huge.
For the first time since video games began, 20 years old titles were selling literally millions of copies again, and a real retro market was born. NES games were are at the top of that, and Mega Man 2 was one of the a best sellers.
Meanwhile, platforms like Wiiware/PSN allowed to publish low budget games made by small teams again.

It was the start of the whole retro video game waves and Mega Man 9 played a huge part in that since it showed everyone you could make new games in the style of old and sell a fuckton of copies

Of course these days the NES is being dismissed in favour of more recent platforms which is why we're getting babies like OP seething

>do you make an effort to actually use them
Absolutely. The point of a singleplayer game is to have a fun experience.

The only reason I would NOT use mechanics like this is if the mechanic makes the gameplay unfun or using them is really clunky. Like FEAR has pretty damn cool melee kicks, I use them occasionally even if they aren't all that useful in the end.

But I certainly use mechanics a lot more if they're well integrated to the core gameplay. Not necessarily mandatory, but if they don't fit to the general flow of the combat / feel fun, then not very likely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597625
You get it right after becoming an adult, and not only does it allow you to progress further, but it unlocks extra exploration potential that you didn't have before. It's the item that really drives home the point that you're in a whole new phase of the game and much more can be done now. The fact that it can hook onto all kinds of surfaces also makes you want to use it everywhere and see where you can go and what you can find.

So, what happened in later games? In MM, you get it relatively late provided you're following the intended path through the game, so while it's just as capable as the OoT Longshot, by that point you've probably explored most places and the game overall just doesn't reward exploration with it quite as much. In TWW you get it REALLY late and it's MUCH more limited in terms of what it can latch on to, so there's close to nothing to do with it past using it in the few places you're meant to use it in the last few dungeons. In TP, while the concept of the Clawshot is cool and doubly so when you get the second one, again, in practice you can only really use it on places you're specifically meant to use it, so exploration potential with it outside of dungeons boils down to finding compatible targets scattered here and there. Likewise with SS, despite the fact you get the double Clawshot much earlier there.

tl;dr it's cool in OoT because you get it at a very appropriate point in the game and the game amply rewards you for trying it out all over the place, and later games clamped down on this aspect in favor of railroading you into using it where they want you to use it.

>>9597448
It's an interesting thought exercise, why not have the hookshot in later 3D Zelda titles, or what benefit would adding the hookshot give?

In the case of Twilight Princess and Skyward Sword, instead of a hookshot, you got the "clawshot", which had limited application as it could only pull you to designated markers rather than to given material surfaces.
In Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask, all the places the hookshot could access were also generally intended, from the right position you could access many spots on a given scene in the game, particularly village rooftops where a secret might be hiding.

Part of changing the hookshot to the clawshot, is that you can no longer rely on commonly placed trees to reach heights.
If you wander around large sprawling maps, the bounds of the playable area usually have large cliff walls which may have trees atop them as decoration. The hookshot would let you get out of bounds too easily, thus the clawshot was introduced to further limit player navigation in a larger world design.

Now, in a game like Breath of the Wild where virtually the entire world map is explorable through air gliding and climbing? A hookshot item wouldn't actually make you able to access any more areas than it previously would, but it might serve to bypass some puzzles or stamina limitations that are in place.
If the hookshot were treated as a tool with durability like bows or rods, it might work; giving the player a chance to quickly reach tricky spots, provide there's a tree or a heavy barrel or something to latch onto.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9598381
This is something I've been thinking about since shortly after SS came out. To me, the hookshot is the definitive example of the problems 3D Zelda developed over time. In OoT, it functioned essentially the way you'd expect it to, meaning, it could latch onto just about anything you'd expect a high-velocity metal hook could (except for trees in the field for some reason). There were dedicated hookshot targets in the game that signaled you to use the hookshot on them, but it could also latch onto plenty of unsignaled objects that gave you freedom in how you moved through the game

In TP/SS, the clawshot can only latch onto dedicated targets (and climbable vines, but that only serves to speed up the climbing rather than to open up any new possibilities) and the games are far more restrictive all around. If you see a clawshot target, you know that you have to use the clawshot, and if you don't see the target, you know there's no point trying to use it. This mentality extends to nearly all the items in both TP and SS. The spinner, for example, would have been a homerun if it functioned just like a regular hoverboard that you could use anywhere, but instead, it only functions on dedicated tracks, and when you see those tracks, you know that the only thing you can do with them is to pull out the spinner. Rather than actually let you flex your problem solving skills, TP and SS just demand that you respond to specific signals, what people might call a "simon says" style of game design. You might not notice it on a first playthrough, but it becomes completely overbearing on replays where you realize you have next to no room to solve the puzzles outside of the one clearly signaled solution

An ideal Zelda game for me would combine BotW's physics that allow for universal applicability of the items with the more traditional world/dungeon design of the earlier games. OoT felt like it was aiming for that, but the games that came after moved in the opposite direction

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9601794
Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other games above already.

its a speculation boom. just like comics in the '90s. basically people started finding rare copies that sold for a lot and it became a market around collecting games and hopes that they would one day be worth thousands of dollars.

but it fails for the same reason it did for comics. when you have something that there are 500,000 copies of and they begin to be collected, then even if the demand is very high, the supply is so common that their inflated value can only be sold to future speculators. the bubble will ultimately burst.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Considering Saturn was a failure outside of Japan, I'd say Dreamcast.

No one in the USA cared about the Saturn in the 1990s. It was a joke to a majority of people. If you went into a game store, it was either Nintendo 64 or Playstation 1 that dominated store shelves. Most stores didn't have a Sega Saturn display section. And if they did, it was tiny and shoved near the clearance section. Saturn was overpriced and just a terrible selection of games in the USA. No Sonic either. How stupid. No one cared about Saturn. And it just died and wasn't even remember by most kids.

Dreamcast at least had hype. I remember retailer's carrying the system and hyping it up. Selling special edition versions like the Black Dreamcast and other colors. It was a big deal. Too bad about Sega going bankrupt (because apparently Saturn drained their finances too much), but Dreamcast sold 3x the amount of the Saturn in half the amount of time. Much more memorable games too. Crazy Taxi, Soul Caliber, Sonic adventure, etc. If only Sega didn't run their business into the ground I'm sure Dreamcast would have done respectable for itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589170
If you had to choose between the Saturn or the Dreamcast for playing games on the original hardware than the clear choice is the Saturn. The Dreamcast is a great system, but the majority of its best games have been ported or re-released on other platforms, whereas the majority of the Saturn's best games are exclusive to the console.

Saturn consoles are still fairly cheap as well, you can get a jap import model with a controller, a memory cart, and sometimes a game or three for around $100 shipped. Spend another $50 on a PseudoSaturn cartridge and you'll be able to play burned games. Alternately you can get an ODE fairly cheaply (from around $140 to around $220, depending on the model).

The Dreamcast can play burned games natively since the copy protection was cracked over 20 years ago, but since the DC supported GD-ROMs (essentially CDs that could store 1GB of data compared to the 700MB you could get out of a CD-ROM) a significant portion of the games on the system have to have data trimmed to make them fit on a CD-R. This usually means stuff like video being heavily downsampled, audio being downsampled, or sometimes audio/video being removed completely. The ODE situation on the Dreamcast is kinda fucked as well (they exist, but availability can be a pain in the dick if you don't want to buy the more expensive model).

Either console will have a solid selection of arcade ports, RPGs, and action games. Neither console had a ton of lightgun games - the Saturn basically has a couple of solid Virtua Cop games, a mediocre port of House of the Dead, and the typical Maximum Force/Area 51 combo (plus a few not stellar others), meanwhile the Dreamcast has a great port of House of the Dead 2 and Confidential Mission (plus a couple more gun sections in other games). Columbine happened in early '99 and basically tanked any US releases of lightgun games for a few years, so the DC got almost none.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597751
>The Dreamcast was a failed hail mary from it inception.

It's pretty sad, because the Dreamcast was basically designed to fix every single problem that developers had with the Saturn:

> The multi-processor architecture on the Saturn is a pain in the ass to code for and port games from other consoles to
The Dreamcast was built with a single powerful CPU
> We needed to utilize the RAM cart to get the best performance because of the low amount of memory, a peripheral that wasn't even released outside of Japan
The Dreamcast shipped with 16MB of RAM, an insane amount for a console in 1999
> It's difficult to get high quality 3D graphics out of the console
The Dreamcast shipped with a powerful GPU, 8MB of VRAM for high quality textures, and hardware antialiasing (meaning AA was essentially "free")
> People were turned off by the Saturn's high pricetag at launch
The Dreamcast launched at half the price of the Saturn, and two thirds the expected price of the PS2
> Coding games for the Saturn is difficult due to the low quality official documentation
Sega made a point to have extensive and widely available hardware documentation for developers
> Porting games from the PC to the Saturn is difficult to impossible
The Dreamcast shipped with WindowsCE support to make porting games from the PC to the console easier (if developers chose to utilize it)
> Coding online multiplayer for Saturn games wasn't worth the time and money spent due to low sales of the Netlink (mostly due to its high cost)
Every Dreamcast launched with a 33.6k or 56.6k dialup modem, and support for a broadband adaptor
> Supporting 3 or more players in games is a waste of time due to the low sales of the multi-tap
The Dreamcast shipped with four controller ports

Pretty much the only steps backward from the Saturn were no onboard save storage, and the controller (losing the 3x2 arcade layout in exchange for a 2x2 diamond as well as using only a single analog stick).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597795
>The Dreamcast launched at half the price of the Saturn, and two thirds the expected price of the PS2

This was probably Sega's only mistake.

Sega should have never sold the Dreamcast at loss (sell it for less than it costs to make it). They would never win against Sony who also sells at a loss but has money to burn.

Nintendo NEVER sells at a loss. Nintendo always sells their consoles for a profit. Even if its a small profit. Sega should have done the same as Nintendo. They can't fight Sony the same way they fought Nintendo.

Plus Sega was actually not in a good financial position before launching the Dreamcast. The failure of the Sega Saturn hurt Sega and bloodied them. Sega didn't actually have the cash reserves to fully support a new system. Maybe if Sega had several more years to recover. But of course that wasn't happening. The Playstation 2 was coming.

So Sega took out loans and went into deep debt to make the Dreamcast happen. The only way to pay the loans back was if the Dreamcast sold huge numbers. Like Sega Genesis numbers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600024
That guy is trying to bait the thread, it's not a serious post.

I do wonder what THPS would have been like on the Saturn though. The control scheme would have to be something like B to ollie, A for kick tricks, C for grab tricks, and Y to grind, with L and R being used for rotations. That would leave X and Z, I don't know if there is anything else that would be useful to be mapped there. Skipping music tracks maybe?

The major thing with a THPS port would be that the framerate would have to be solid. It has Steep Slope Sliders, which runs well, as well as a couple other Japanese snowboarding games. I think it would be doable. The PS1 version has a few large open levels, but it also has very aggressive fogging to keep the draw distance down.

Getting THPS2, 3, and 4 running on the console would have been a struggle I think though. With THPS2 the skater models and skater/environment textures had a huge increase in quality (THPS3 and 4 on the PS1 are basically just reskins of THPS2 with new moves).

How is the Saturn hooked up? If you're doing composite, you can get a cheap splitter and run one set of cables to the projector and one set to a CRT TV and set it under the projector's screen.
